content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A private fund is an issuer that would be an investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 but for certain exceptions. A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a US place of business and with fewer than 15 US clients in the past 12 months. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a US place of business, with fewer than 15 US clients in the past 12 months, and assets under management in the US of less than $25,000,000. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a US place of business, with fewer than 15 US clients in the past 12 months, and assets under management in the US of less than $25,000,000. The amendment also specifies that a foreign private fund adviser must not hold itself out generally to the public in the United States as an investment adviser or act as an investment adviser to any registered investment company. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, the amendment specifies that any investment adviser solely advising a private fund is also included. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. The Commission is authorized to provide reports or records to entities identified as having systemic risk responsibility. Records and reports of private funds advised by investment advisers are deemed to be the investment adviser's records. The records and reports of private funds advised by investment advisers must include information such as assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant data as required by the Commission. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report information on leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant data deemed necessary for the public interest, investor protection, or systemic risk assessment. The Commission may require additional information from private fund advisers as necessary, considering public interest and systemic risk. Different reporting requirements may apply based on the types or sizes of private funds advised. Registered investment advisers must maintain records of private funds for specified periods to protect investors and assess systemic risk. Investment advisers registered under the Act must maintain records of private funds for specified periods for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission can conduct periodic examinations of these records as needed. Investment advisers registered under the Act must undergo periodic examinations by the Commission or its representatives. They are required to provide copies of records upon request. The Commission shares information with the Federal Reserve System and other identified entities. The Commission requires investment advisers to undergo periodic examinations and provide requested records. Information is shared with the Federal Reserve System and other identified entities for assessing systemic risk of private funds. The purpose of assessing systemic risk of private funds involves keeping obtained information confidential as per Commission guidelines. Investment advisers must disclose certain private fund information to investors, counterparties, and creditors as prescribed by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission may prescribe disclosure of private fund information to investors, counterparties, and creditors for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Reports filed with the Commission under this subsection are confidential and not subject to disclosure. The Commission is not authorized to withhold information from Congress or other federal agencies, self-regulatory organizations, or comply with court orders. This paragraph is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision and provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the requirement to maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. These advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 exempts advisers of private funds with assets under $150,000,000 from registration. They must maintain records and provide reports to the Commission. The Commission will regulate mid-sized private fund advisers based on their size, governance, and investment strategy to assess systemic risk. Registration and examination procedures will be tailored to the level of risk posed by these funds. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to give the Commission authority to make rules and regulations based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk. The Commission has the authority to classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk. It can also prescribe different requirements for different classes and ascribe different meanings to terms as necessary to achieve the purposes of the Act. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission shall jointly promulgate rules within 12 months to establish the form and content of reports required to be filed by investment advisers registered under the Investment Advisers Act of 2009. The Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 requires the Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to jointly establish rules for reports filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. SEC. 9. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period from the enactment date. The SEC will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. The Commission will adjust dollar amount tests for inflation every 5 years. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
